* [Aggregator](#aggregator)
* [Source](#source)

## Aggregator
The Aggregator Git Repo comes with its own docker-compose file, meant to aid in development. It defines two services: `run` and `test`.

### Run

As the name suggests, `run` is meant for a once-off run of the system. It mimics _production ready_ as much as possible. For example, it will spin up and configure Redis cache services. It will use a real HTTP adapter to send the fetched and formatted data onto a [storage systems](#source). At the same time, it will also mount the source-code into the container for development.

It is set up in such a way that all its HTTP PUT/POST/PATCH request will be sent to the host operating system. This allows for all of the systems/services that make up the Althingi system to use the host operating systems as its _network bridge_, so to say. It is not required to set up a dedicated Docker network and then try to connect all the different running docker containers into it. Instead, all the different services will communicate through the host's feedback network adapter (localhost/127.0.0.1).

The `run` service can be configured through ENV parameters but the default values should be fine for development.

| name                       | type             | default              | description |
| -------------------------- | ---------------- | -------------------- | ----------- |
| CONSUMER_CACHE_TYPE        | none/redis       | none                 | If Redis cache for Consumer should be used or not. |
| CONSUMER_CACHE_HOST        | service-name     | cache-consumer       | If Redis cache for Consumer is on, the name of the service (or an IP address) |
| CONSUMER_CACHE_PORT        | number           | 6379                 | If Redis cache for Consumer is on, the port number of that service |
| PROVIDER_CACHE_TYPE        | none/redis       | none                 | If Redis cache for Producer should be used or not |
| PROVIDER_CACHE_HOST        | service-name     | cache-provider       | If Redis cache for Producer is on, the name of the service (or an IP address) |
| PROVIDER_CACHE_PORT        | number           | 6379                 | If Redis cache for Producer is on, the port number of that service |
| AGGREGATOR_CONSUMER_SCHEMA | http/https       | http                 | The protocol used by the Storage system |
| AGGREGATOR_CONSUMER_HOST   | string           | host.docker.internal | The IP address/name of the Storage system. The default is the host's IP address |
| AGGREGATOR_CONSUMER_PORT   | number           | 7070                 | The port used by the Storage system. The default is 7070 which is the same as is used in the [docker-compose development](https://github.com/fizk/althingi-source/blob/main/docker-compose.ym) file |

    <figcaption>
        The Aggregator docker container will send HTTP request out into the host's network interface. This very much implies that <a href="#source">Source</a> is also running on the host system so they can talk to each other.
    </figcaption>
</figure>

To run a once-off Aggregator task, simply select the task that should be run by calling

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm run <task-name> [parameters]
```

Where task-name can be

**global**
: Will collect information which is shared across many Assemblies. It is best to always call this first as other tasks might depend on resources that this task creates.

**assembly** [assembly number]
: Gets everything related to one Assembly
: Is expecting one argument, the number of Assembly

**issue** [assembly number] [issue number] [category a/b]
: Get everything related to one Issue
: Is expecting three arguments, the Assembly number, the Issue number and the category A or B

An example of calling the `issue` task could look like this

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm  run issue 150 1 A
```

### Test
Test is the service that is called by the build-agent when the system is deployed, so it's very much configured to be able to run its test in isolation. It doesn't spin up the Redis cache services and it doesn't use the HTTP adapter to offload its data.

This service can also be used to run test while in development. A good way to do that is to go into the container and run tests from there.

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm test bash
```
..and once inside, there are two aliases that can be used to simplyfy the running of php-unit-tests

**phpunit** [params]
: Alias to run PhpUnit
: It will alway require the path to the `tests` directory but can optinally accept a filter query
: Example: `$ phpunit --filter=nameOfTestMethod ./tests`

**cover** [params]
: Alias to run PhpUnit's code-coverage
: It will alway require the path to the `tests` directory but can optinally accept a filter query
: It will produce the results in HTML format in the `tests/docs` directory.
: example `$ cover ./tests`

The reason why the `./tests` directory is not a part of the alias is becaue you might want to only run tests in a sub-directory. For example, to only run the **Handler** tests, you can run this command

```sh
$ phpunit ./tests/Handler
```

### Development
The way I like to do development is to simply use the `test` service as defined in the docker-compose file like this:

1. Clone the repo
2. `cd` into the project directory
3. Start a `test` container by running `$ docker compose run --rm test bash` which will
    * Mount the `config`, `src`, `public` and `test` into the container
    * Run Composer and install all dependencies
    * Leave me in an interactice terminal where I can run `phpunit`
    * It will additionally install Composer dependencies into my host system, but mount it back into the docker container so I can step through the dependency code with the debugger.
4. Write my code and test and have them run inside the docker container.

### Debugger.
If either the `run` or `test` is built with the `--build-arg` parameter set to `development` (which the docker-compose file does by default), Xdebug is enabled.

It sets `xdebug.client_host` to `host.docker.internal` and `xdebug.client_port` to `9003`, so a default configured Debugger should be able to pick up Xdebug though `localhost`.

## Source
The Source repos comes with its own docker-compose file which is meant for development. It defines two services: `run` and `test` along with services that define the database for those two services.

### Run
Use `run` to initialise a running instance of Source. It mimics the _production ready_ version but has configuration meant for development. The Source's Dockerfile can be built in two modes: `production` or `development`. The docker-compose, by default will build the containers in `development` mode. This will install Xdebug and expose it to the host's networks through the magic of `host.docker.internal`. It will not optimise Composer auto-load.

The docker-compose will expose the Apache server on port `7070` so the API can be accessed through `http://localhost:7070`.

The docker-compose file will also create a MySQL database instance and connect it to the API. Its port is exposed on port `3306`. So a GUI tool can gain access to it if required.

This aligns with what the [Aggregator](#aggregator) is expecting. It's expecting to be able to connect to a Source that is accessible through the host's network (aka localhost).

When ever the database changes, a Kafka event is is fired off. This might not be applicable in development. Therefor this can be turned off by an ENV variable

| name                       | type             | default              | description |
| -------------------------- | ---------------- | -------------------- | ----------- |
| ENV_BROKER                 | none/kafka       | kafka                | Sets the name of the Queue that will liten for change events, or `none` if no events should be sent out |

The Kafka host is hard-coded to `host.docker.internal:9092`, so again, it is expected that Kafka is also accessible through the host's network (aka localhost).

The database has it's data directory mounted to a Docker Volume named `local-source-db-volume` this is to not loose any data if the container is removed.

Lastly, all the source-code directories are monted into the container for development, this includes things like: `config`, `src`, `tests`, `public`, `bin` and `vendor`.

### Test
Test is the service that is run by the build-agent in the CI/CD pipeline, so it's configured to run in isolation. It doesn't depend on Kafka and it has its own instance of a database where that database can be truncated and rebuilt with out it affecting the `run` database.

The build agent will run

```sh
$ docker compose run test
```
What will happen is that, because the `test` service has a dependency on `database-test`, it will use [wait-for-it.sh](https://github.com/vishnubob/wait-for-it/blob/master/wait-for-it.sh) to wait until the database is ready before running the unit-test

I like to use the `test` service to write my unit-test. What I will do is to spin up a container in a _bash_ and then run my unit-tests from there. Because Xdebug is already configured and I have a configured Debugger, I'm able to step though my code.

To gain access to a running test container, simply run

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm test bash
```

Once inside the container, there are two simple shortcuts you can use

```sh
$ phpunit [path]
```
or
```sh
$ cover
```

**phpunit**
: Is a shortcut to call the `./vendor/bin/phpunit`.
: It expects to get a path, which is usually `./tests`.
: You can also pass additional filters like `$ phpunit --filter=nameofmethod ./tests/somefile.php`.

**cover**
: Will run phpunit and then generate a code-coverage report in HTML format.
: The report will be placed in `./tests/docs`.

### Development
To get up and running for development, simply do:

1. Clone the repo
2. `cd` to the project root
3. Run `docker compose up -d run`

If you would like to gain access to a container deticated to unit-test, you should spin up the `test` service because it has it's own instance of a database and will not delete data from the `run` database instance.

1. Clone the repo
2. `cd` to the project root
3. Run `docker compose run --rm test bash`

Once inside the container, you can run unit-test by calling `$ phpunit ./tests`.

### Database
You might sometimes nees to either export the database or import data into it, for that you can run:

To make a dump of the database, run
```sh
docker exec local-althingi-source-db /usr/bin/mysqldump -u root --password=example althingi > path/to/backup.sql
```

To import dump into the database
```sh
docker exec -i local-althingi-source-db mysql -u root --password=example althingi < path/to/backup.sql
```

### Debugger
Like stated previously, Xdebug is configured by default in the docker-compose file, by passing the `--build-arg=development`. Xdebug is configured to send debug information to the host system through `host.docker.internal` (aka localhost) on port `9003`. This should be inline with what most debuggers are expecting.

### Re-indexing
Sometimes during development, you might want to force Source to fire off Kafka events. Obviouldy would would need to have set up Kafka and the Messaging services.

The Source service has a script that can send out `Add` events. To run it:

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm run index console
```

This will give you a list of all the commands available and which arguments are required. For example, to re-index all issues for a given assembly, run:

```sh
$ docker compose run --rm run index console:issue --assembly_id=140
```
